Input.threadtitle: Supernovae asymmetry
Input.posts:
When looking at the images of a supernova remnant how can you determine whether asymmetries observed are due to asymmetry of the SN explosion or asymmetry of the pre SN clouds of ejecta? In the early days of the SN explosion I would think most of the asymmetry would be from the explosion because, if I understand correctly, most of the high energy emissions come from radioactive decay of isotopes created in the explosion. Later however, and several hundred years would constitute much later, Isn't most of the light due to the shock wave and photons from the explosion interacting with pre-SN ejecta?\xA0 How do you differentiate between asymmetrical density of the ejecta and asymmetries in energy and material from the explosion. For example, is one differentiated by spectral content and the other by amplitude? I'm sure it isn't that simple but hopefully you get what I am driving at. Brad Walter edit corrected typo
Upvotes:
3
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
That's a really good question and one I'd like to know the answer to as well!\xA0 I would assume that the initial explosion is mostly symmetric, if not spherically then along the star's axis of rotation (but I could be very mistaken here).\xA0 A bit of grubbing around on ADS (the Astrophysical Data System, run by SAO/NASA) brings up some interesting ideas.\xA0 Many supernovae seem to have bipolar asymmetry (see http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2006ApJ...645..283F and http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2001ApJ...550.1030W ), possibly caused by high energy jets (see also http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?arXiv:astro-ph/0606224 ).\xA0 It's a really complicated subject, and one which I don't feel confident giving any definitive answer (apologies!).

Input.threadtitle: How many photons in 1/2 arc second of the sky?
Input.posts:
In the second video of Week 2 we learn that 1 pixel in DS9 represents 1/2 arc second of the sky. Later in the video when we look at the Quick Energy Spectrum Plot we see a plot showing the distribution of photons by Energy (eV). Does the software know how many photons are in 1/2 arc second of the sky? Does that not vary depending on which part of the sky we are looking at? How does the software know this?
Upvotes:
1
\xA0if you mean in the number of photons per interval of time that strike a pixel of your detector that has a field of view 1/2 arcsecond wide pointed at different points of the sky the answer is definitely that it varies by location. If you point your telescope at a dense, relatively nearby globular cluster you will collect more photons \xA0than if you point it at a relatively empty region of space. If However, you mean is there a constant \xA0quantity of photons passing through a fixed volume of space as you move that volume around the universe the answer is also that it varies, but this brings up an interesting question called Olbers' Paradox. If stars were essentially evenly distributed in the volume of space on an extremely large scale - say on the order of the scale of galaxy superclusters, why isn't the night sky essentially uniformly bright? The volume of stars would go up as the cube of the radius but light intensity falls off only as the square? If the Universe is infinitely big, doesn't every line of sight fall on a star? The question is far from trivial.\xA0The solution to the paradox within our current understanding\xA0is summarized here.\xA0 http://curious.astro.cornell.edu/question.php?number=375
Upvotes:
2
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
To clarify, the relationship between the size of a pixel and the angular distance that it corresponds to will vary depending on the telescope being used.\xA0 The detector is actually counting the number of photons, and when you keep track of the energy of each photon, you can describe the spectrum of that source.\xA0 So in answer to your questions, the photon counts will change as you point your telescope in different directions, and the information telling you about this is in the image taken be your telescope.

Prof Matilsky essentially says that each portion of the electromagnetic spectrum has quantum energies appropriate for the\xA0 excitation of certain types of physical processes. The energy levels for all physical\xA0 processes at the atomic and molecular levels are quantized, and if there are no available\xA0 quantized energy levels with spacings which match the quantum energy of the incident\xA0 radiation, then the material will be transparent to that radiation, and it will pass\xA0 through. OK,my question applies specifically to the absorption of a photon by an electron. What is the mechanism whereby only a photon with the right energy is absorbed. How does the photon-electron system 'know' which photons are to absorbed and which photons are to be ignored? Seems to me there must be some measurement or exchange of information by the system (a la Maxwell's demon). Any comments or pointers will be welcome.\xA0
